Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the benefits received by members of Congress in terms of their pensions and the amount they receive until they die.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that members of Congress do not contribute to the Social Security fund.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that members of Congress receive lavish pensions after only one term in office without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or factors that may contribute to the pension benefits received by members of Congress.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that members of Congress do contribute to their own retirement plans, although the specific details of their plans may vary.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity and nuances of the pension and retirement plans available to members of Congress.
